awd_titl_txt: Many-Body Dipole-Dipole Interactions in Atomic Ensembles
awd_abstract_narration:
Many-body interactions play important roles in a variety of systems ranging from simple atoms to complex biological molecules.  Dipole-dipole interactions are essential in protein formation and folding.  The interactions can lead to collective and emergent phenomena that cannot be understood by a simple extrapolation of the microscopic laws of a few particles. The research supported by this NSF award aims to gain an experimentally confirmed understanding of many-body dipole-dipole interactions in atomic ensembles. This will be accomplished by using an advanced laser spectroscopic technique that is uniquely sensitive to many-body interactions in complex systems. The experimental results will be compared to simulated results to help develop a theoretical model. This research will contribute to the general understanding of many-body physics in an ensemble of interacting particles, which has profound implications in fields ranging from optical atomic clocks to photosynthesis. The experimental and theoretical approaches developed in the project can be used to study other many-body systems as well. This project also includes efforts to enhance the capacity to train students at Florida International University, a minority serving institution, in science and technology, to strengthen the education of underrepresented groups in the STEM fields. 

The goal of this project is to quantitatively understand many-body dipole-dipole interactions in atomic ensembles, at densities varying across nine orders of magnitude, and both with or without the presence of thermal motion. The effects of dipole-dipole interactions will be probed by double-quantum two-dimensional coherent spectroscopy, which provides a sensitive and background-free detection of many-body dipole-dipole interactions. The temporal resolution of femtosecond laser pulses allows one to probe the dynamics during the transient processes of interactions. The experiments will be performed on a hot atomic rubidium vapor and also with cold rubidium atoms. The hot atomic vapor provides a broad range of mean interatomic separations and many-body dynamics associated with thermal motion. In comparison, the cold atoms provide an environment in the virtual absence of thermal motion.   Comparing the results from cold and hot atoms enables this group to study the effects of thermal motion on the dipole-dipole interactions. The resulting structural and dynamic information will contribute to the development of a theoretical model based on the exciton formalism that accounts for the dipole-dipole interactions in an atomic ensemble. The study will determine fundamental parameters such as dipole-dipole interaction strength, effective interaction range, the number of interacting atoms, excitation-induced many-body states, effects of a buffer gas, and effects of thermal motion of the dipole-dipole interaction in atomic ensembles.

por.por_cntn:
In this project titled "Many-body dipole-dipole interactions in atomic ensembles", the PI has studied many-body dipole-dipole interactions and correlations in atomic vapors and cold atoms. The dipole-dipole interaction plays an important role in many systems such as cold atoms/molecules, optical atomic clocks, semiconductors, and photosynthesis. Its long-range nature extends the interaction beyond nearest neighbors, leading to many-body phenomena that cannot be explained by simply extrapolating the microscopic laws of individual particles. It is essential to experimentally understand many-body dipole-dipole interactions and correlations.

Through this project, the PI?s laboratory at Florida International University (FIU) has developed new experimental and theoretical capabilities to study dipole-dipole interactions and many-body correlations in atomic ensembles. The effects of many-body interactions were probed by using optical double-quantum two-dimensional coherent spectroscopy (2DCS), which provides extremely sensitive and background-free detection. The study acquired quantitative experimental results that are important for the fundamental understanding of dipole-dipole interaction strength, effective interaction range, the number of interacting atoms, interaction dynamics, excitation-induced many-body states, and effects of a buffer gas. Particularly, the experiment was able to probe the dipole-dipole interaction between two atoms that are as far apart as 16 micrometers or 300 thousand the size of atom; the effects of dipole-dipole interaction were measured as the interatomic separation changes over orders of magnitude; multi-atom states with up to eight atoms were created and detected; the dynamics of dipole-dipole interactions were measured at the picosecond time scale; the effects of dipole-dipole interactions were measured with different laser excitation powers; the effects of a buffer gas was measured; the technique of optical 2DCS was successfully implemented in cold atoms and single atoms in a vapor. These results have been published in six peer-reviewed journal papers and presented in six conference presentations. Several more publications based on these results are in preparation. To a broader impact, the established research program and developed research techniques in the project can be used to study many-body physics in other systems such as single molecules, color centers, 2D materials, perovskites, other semiconductor nanostructures, and photosynthetic systems.

Towards the educational goals, the PI developed a new graduate-level course on the topic of ?Ultrafast and nonlinear optics?. The course has been taught 3 times to a total of 22 students from three different departments at FIU and will be offered to more students beyond the performance period of this project. The PI has been actively engaging and mentoring both undergraduate and graduate students in research activities. During this project, the PI?s laboratory provided research opportunities to 4 graduate students and 9 undergraduate students, the majority of who are from underrepresented minority groups. Many of these students have graduated and successfully continued to the next stage of their scientific careers.
